current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to improve and extend the deduction for new and existing
			 energy-efficient commercial buildings, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

header.#text: Short title; amendment of 1986 Code; table of contents

text.#text:
This Act may be
		cited as the

Except as otherwise
		expressly provided, whenever in this Act an amendment or repeal is
		expressed in terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other
		provision, the reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other
		provision of the
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; amendment of 1986 Code; table of contents.
Sec. 101. Extension and modification of deduction for energy-efficient commercial buildings.
Sec. 102. Deduction for retrofits of existing commercial and multifamily buildings.
Sec. 201. Performance based home energy improvements.
TITLE III—Industrial Energy and Water Efficiency
Sec. 301. Modifications in credit for combined heat and power system property.
Sec. 302. Investment tax credit for biomass heating property.
Sec. 303. Investment tax credit for waste heat to power property.
Sec. 304. Motor energy efficiency improvement tax credit.
Sec. 305. Credit for replacement of CFC refrigerant chiller.
Sec. 306. Qualifying efficient industrial process water use project credit.

text.#text:
With respect to property that is part of a lighting system, the deduction allowed under subsection
			 (a) shall be equal to—

for a lighting system that includes installation of a lighting control described in paragraph
			 (2)(A), the applicable amount determined under paragraph (3)(A),

for a lighting system that includes installation of a lighting control described in paragraph
			 (2)(B), the applicable amount determined under paragraph (3)(B), or

for a lighting system that does not include installation of any lighting controls described in
			 subparagraph (A) or (B) of paragraph (2), the applicable amount
			 determined under paragraph (3)(C).

Occupancy sensors (as described in paragraph (4)(I))
		  in spaces not greater than 800 square feet.

Bi-level
		  controls (as described in paragraph (4)(A)).
Continuous or step dimming controls (as described in subparagraphs (B) and (K) of paragraph (4)).

Daylight dimming where sufficient daylight is
		  available (as described in paragraph (4)(C)).
A multi-scene controller (as described in paragraph (4)(H)).

Time scheduling controls (as described in paragraph (4)(L)), provided that such controls are not
			 required by Standard 90.1-2010.
Such other lighting controls as the

For purposes of paragraph (1)(A), the lighting controls described in this subparagraph are the
			 following:
Occupancy sensors (as described in paragraph (4)(I)) in spaces greater	than 800 square feet.
Demand responsive controls (as described in paragraph (4)(D)).
Lumen maintenance controls (as described in paragraph (4)(F)) where solid state lighting is used.
Such other lighting controls as the

For purposes of paragraph (1)(B), the lighting controls described in this subparagraph are the

text.#text: For purposes of this subsection:

term.#tail: means a lighting control strategy that provides for 2 different levels of lighting.

means a lighting control strategy that adjusts the light output of a lighting system between

adjusts electric lighting power in response to the amount of daylight that is present in an area,
			 and

provides for separate control of the lamps for general lighting in the daylight area by not less

			 that satisfies the following requirements:

The light sensor for the multi-level photocontrol is remote from where calibration adjustments are

The calibration adjustments are readily accessible.

The multi-level photocontrol reduces electric lighting power in response to the amount of daylight

not less than 1 control step that is between 50 percent and 70 percent of design lighting power,
			 and
not less than 1 control step that is not less than 35 percent of design lighting power.

header.#text:
Special rule
		for partnerships and S corporations

text.#text:
In the case of a partnership
		  or S corporation, this section shall be applied at the partner or shareholder
		  level, subject to such reporting requirements as are determined appropriate by
		  the

header.#text:
Special rule
		  for partnerships and S corporations

text.#text:
Except as otherwise provided, the amendments made by this
		section shall apply to property placed in service in taxable years beginning
		after the date of the enactment of this Act.

header.#text:
Deduction for
		retrofits of existing commercial and multifamily buildings

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal
		Revenue Code of 1986

header.#text:
Deduction for
		  retrofits of existing commercial and multifamily buildings

text.#text:
With respect to each certified retrofit plan, there shall
		  be allowed as a deduction an amount equal to the lesser of—

the sum
		  of—

the
		  design deduction, and

the
		  realized deduction, or

the
		  total cost to develop and implement such certified retrofit plan.

For
		  purposes of the amount described in paragraph (1)(B), if such amount is taken
		  as a design deduction, no realized deduction shall be allowed.
For purposes of this section—
A design deduction shall be—

based on
		  projected source energy savings as calculated in accordance with subsection
		  (c)(3)(B),

correlated to the
		  percent of source energy savings set forth in the general scale in paragraph
		  (3)(A) that a certified retrofit plan is projected to achieve when
		  energy-efficient measures are placed in service, and

equal to 60
		  percent of the amount allowed under the general scale.

based
		  on realized source energy savings as calculated in accordance with subsection
		  (c)(3)(C),

correlated to
		  the percent of source energy savings set forth in the general scale in
		  paragraph (3)(A) as realized by a certified retrofit plan, and

equal to 40
		  percent of the amount allowed under the general scale.
A realized deduction shall be—

The percent of source energy savings for
		  purposes of any realized deduction may vary from such savings projected when
		  energy-efficient measures were placed in service for purposes of a design
		  deduction under paragraph (1).

Notwithstanding the regulations prescribed under
		  subsection (f), no recapture of a design deduction shall be required where the
		  owner of the commercial or multifamily building—

claims or
		  allocates a design deduction when energy-efficient measures are placed into
		  service pursuant to the terms and conditions of a certified retrofit plan,
		  and

is not eligible
		  for or does not subsequently claim or allocate a realized deduction.

$1.00
		  per square foot of retrofit floor area for 20 to 24 percent source energy
		  savings,

$1.50 per square
		  foot of retrofit floor area for 25 to 29 percent source energy savings,

$2.00 per
		  square foot of retrofit floor area for 30 to 34 percent source energy
		  savings,

$2.50 per square
		  foot of retrofit floor area for 35 to 39 percent source energy savings,

$3.00
		  per square foot of retrofit floor area for 40 to 44 percent source energy
		  savings,

$3.50 per square
		  foot of retrofit floor area for 45 to 49 percent source energy savings,
		  and

$4.00 per
		  square foot of retrofit floor area for 50 percent or more source energy
		  savings.

The scale for deductions allowed under this section shall
		  be—

With respect to energy-efficient measures placed in
		  service as part of a certified retrofit plan in a commercial building or
		  multifamily building on or eligible for the National Register of Historic
		  Places, the respective dollar amounts set forth in the general scale under
		  subparagraph (A) shall—

each be increased
		  by 20 percent, for the purposes of calculating any applicable design deduction
		  and realized deduction, and

not exceed the total cost to develop and implement such certified retrofit
		  plan.

If
		  the amount described in clause (i)(II) is taken as a design deduction, then no
		  realized deduction shall be allowed.

For purposes of the design deduction and the realized
		  deduction, source energy savings shall be calculated with reference to a
		  baseline of the annual source energy consumption of the commercial or
		  multifamily building before energy-efficient measures were placed in
		  service.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and based upon 1 year of
		  source energy consumption data prior to the date upon which the
		  energy-efficient measures are placed in service.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency

text.#text:
The baseline under paragraph (1) shall be determined
		  using a building energy performance benchmarking tool designated by the

In certifying a retrofit plan as a certified retrofit
		  plan, a licensed engineer or architect shall calculate source energy savings by
		  utilizing the baseline benchmark defined in paragraph (2) and determining
		  percent improvements from such baseline.

For purposes of claiming a design deduction, the
		  regulations issued under subsection (f)(1) shall prescribe the standards and
		  process for a licensed engineer or architect to calculate and certify source
		  energy savings projected from the design of a certified retrofit plan as of the
		  date energy-efficient measures are placed in service.

For purposes of claiming a realized deduction, a
		  licensed engineer or architect shall calculate and certify source energy
		  savings realized by a certified retrofit plan 2 years after a design deduction
		  is allowed by utilizing energy consumption data after energy-efficient measures
		  are placed in service, and adjusting for climate, building occupancy hours,
		  density, or other factors deemed appropriate in the benchmarking tool
		  designated under paragraph (2).

header.#text:
Design and
		  realized source energy savings

text.#text:
For purposes of this
		  section—

header.#text:
Certified
		  retrofit plan and other definitions

term.#tail:
means
		  a plan that—

text.#text: The term

is designed to
		  reduce the annual source energy costs of a commercial building, or a
		  multifamily building, through the installation of energy-efficient
		  measures,

is certified
		  under penalty of perjury by a licensed engineer or architect, who is not a
		  direct employee of the owner of the commercial building or multifamily building
		  that is the subject of the plan, and is licensed in the State in which such
		  building is located,

describes the
		  square footage of retrofit floor area covered by such a plan,

specifies that it
		  is designed to achieve a final source energy usage intensity after
		  energy-efficient measures are placed in service in a commercial building or a
		  multifamily building that does not exceed on a square foot basis the average
		  level of energy usage intensity of other similar buildings, as described in
			 paragraph (2),

requires that
		  after the energy-efficient measures are placed in service, the commercial
		  building or multifamily building meets the applicable State and local
		  building code requirements for the area in which such building is
		  located,

satisfies the
		  regulations prescribed under subsection (f), and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
after energy-efficient measures are placed in service,
		  for the purpose of informing the report to

text.#text:
is submitted to
		  the

The maximum average level of energy usage intensity under paragraph (1)(D) shall not exceed 300,000
			 British thermal units per square foot.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall
			 develop distinct standards for categories and subcategories of buildings
			 with respect to maximum average level of energy usage intensity based on
			 the best available information used by the ENERGY STAR program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of the Environmental Protection
			 Agency

text.#text:
that
		  is in existence and occupied on the date of the enactment of this
		  section,

for
		  which a certificate of occupancy has been issued at least 10 years before
		  energy efficiency measures are placed in service, and

with a primary
		  use or purpose other than as residential housing.

term.#tail:
means a
		  building located in the United States—

text.#text: The term

text.#text:
In the case of an individual, there shall be allowed as a
				credit against the tax imposed by this chapter for the taxable year
			 for a
				qualified whole home energy efficiency retrofit an amount
			 determined under
				subsection (b).

Subject to paragraph (4), the amount determined under
				this subsection is equal to—

the base amount
				under paragraph (2), increased by

the amount
				determined under paragraph (3).

For purposes of paragraph (1)(A), the base amount is
				$2,000, but only if the energy use for the residence is reduced by
			 at least 20
				percent below the baseline energy use for such residence as
			 calculated
				according to paragraph (5).

For purposes of paragraph (1)(B), the amount determined
				under this paragraph is $500 for each additional 5 percentage point
			 reduction
				in energy use.

In
				no event shall the amount determined under this subsection exceed
			 the lesser
				of—

$5,000 with
				respect to any residence, or

30 percent of the
				qualified home energy efficiency expenditures paid or incurred by
			 the taxpayer
				under subsection (c) with respect to such residence.
For purposes of this subsection—

The reduction in energy use for any residence shall be
				determined by modeling the annual predicted percentage reduction in
			 total
				energy costs for heating, cooling, hot water, and permanent
			 lighting. It shall
				be modeled using computer modeling software approved under
			 subsection (d)(2)
				and a baseline energy use calculated according to subsection
			 (d)(1)(C).

For purposes of subparagraph (A), the energy cost per unit
				of fuel for each fuel type shall be determined by dividing the
			 total actual
				energy bill for the residence for that fuel type for the most
			 recent available
				12-month period by the total energy units of that fuel type used
			 over the same
				period.

For purposes of this section, the
				term

means any amount
				paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the taxable year for a

				home energy efficiency retrofit, including the cost of diagnostic

				labor, and modeling,

				by the

does not include
				any amount which is paid or incurred in connection with any
			 expansion of the
				building envelope of the residence.

For purposes of this
				section—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subpart E of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1

header.#text:
Qualifying
				efficient industrial process water use project credit

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the qualifying efficient
				industrial process water use project credit for any taxable year is
			 an amount
				equal to the applicable percentage of the qualified investment for
			 such taxable
				year with respect to any qualifying efficient industrial process
			 water use
				project of the taxpayer.

text.#text: For purposes of
For purposes of subsection (a)—

10 percent in the
				case of a qualifying efficient industrial process water use project
			 which
				achieves a 25 percent or greater (but less than 50 percent)
			 reduction in water
				use for industrial purposes,

20 percent in
				the case of a qualifying efficient industrial process water use
			 project which
				achieves a 50 percent or greater (but less than 75 percent)
			 reduction in water
				use for industrial purposes, and

30 percent in
				the case of a qualifying efficient industrial process water use
			 project which
				achieves a 75 percent or greater reduction in water use for
			 industrial
				purposes.
The applicable percentage is—

The taxpayer shall elect one of the methods specified in
				clause (ii) for measuring the reduction in water use achieved by a
			 qualifying
				efficient industrial process water use project.

An election under subclause (I), once made with respect
				to a qualifying efficient industrial process water use project,
			 shall apply to
				the taxable year for which made and all subsequent taxable years,
			 and may not
				be revoked.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) to the taxpayer or the installer of eligible
			 property, to
				be achieved by a qualifying efficient industrial process water use
			 project.
				Such projection, if used as a basis for determining the credit
			 under subsection
				(a), shall be included with the return of tax.

text.#text:
The credit under subsection (a) may be claimed on the
				basis of a reduction in water use which is projected, by a
			 registered
				professional engineer who is not a related person (within the
			 meaning of

header.#text:
Measurement of
				reduction in water use

text.#text:
a measurement of
				the percentage reduction in water use per unit of product
			 manufactured by the
				taxpayer, and

a measurement of

			 manufactured by the
				taxpayer.
The methods specified in this clause are—
For purposes of subparagraph (A)—

For purposes of subsection (a), the qualified investment
				for any taxable year is the basis of eligible property placed in
			 service by the
				taxpayer during such taxable year which is part of a qualifying
			 efficient
				industrial process water use project.

Such
				term shall not include any portion of the basis related to—
permitting,

land acquisition,
				or

infrastructure
				not directly associated with the implementation of the technology
			 or process
				improvements of the qualifying efficient industrial process water
			 use
				project.

text.#text:
The
				amount which is treated for all taxable years with respect to any
			 qualifying
				efficient industrial process water use project with respect to any
			 site shall
				not exceed $10,000,000.

For
				purposes of this section—

term.#tail:
means, with respect to any site, a project which
				retrofits or expands an existing facility to implement technology
			 or process
				improvements which are designed to reduce water use for systems
			 that use any
				form of water in the production of goods in the manufacturing
			 sector (as
				defined in North American Industrial Classification System codes
			 31, 32, and
				33), including any system that uses water for heating, cooling, or
			 energy
				production for the production of goods in the trade or business of
				manufacturing (other than extraction of fossil fuels). Such term
			 shall not include a project which alters an existing
				facility to change the type of goods produced by such facility.

qualifying efficient industrial process
				water use project

does not include any
